Inappropriate clotting (thrombosis) stemming from alterations in blood flow is a primary concern with nearly all major cardiovascular diseases, surgeries, and devices. Conceptually, blood flow influences thrombosis in two general ways: by imparting forces and directing transport. However, mechanistic understandings of these processes remain poorly defined. This has been a critical barrier in addressing why certain flow features correlate favorably, or unfavorably, to thrombotic events.

The objective of this project is to develop tools and insights needed to determine the mechanisms by which local disturbances in blood flow potentiate pathological clot formation. This will be accomplished through advancements in computational blood flow modeling and analysis, along with empirical data collected to help guide and validate the numerical findings. This work will specifically address how altered flow leads to thrombus formation in stenotic arteries, which is the primary cause of heart attack and stroke. Recent results have uncovered striking and synergistic interactions between fluid forces and transport mechanisms that are consistent with clinical observations of stenotic thrombus. There is substantial broader potential to use the tools and insights developed by this project to address what hemodynamic conditions are important, and how they are best modeled, identified and conveyed.

This project will foster education on several fronts uniquely suited to PI's environment. Important findings and techniques will be integrated by the Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT) Mathematics and Science Education department into ongoing STEM curriculum development to promote engineering to K-5 students, and into the IIT Boeing Scholars Academy Program for Chicagoland high school students. The design, fabrication and testing of experimental models used to support this research will be incorporated into IIT's unique Interprofessional Projects Program, instructed by the PI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Local blood flow mechanics, along with coagulation and vessel injury, are primary factors affecting intravascular blood clotting (thrombosis). But while hemodynamic factors, such as stasis, are known to be important to thrombosis, the relationship is complex. This project developed computational methods to improve the modeling and characterization of fluid mechanic factors potentially affecting thrombosis. The focus was on large artery hemodynamics due to the importance of thrombosis, and propensity for complex flow, in such vessels. 

Understanding the relationship between hemodynamics and arterial thrombosis is difficult in part because characterization of arterial blood flow mechanics alone is difficult. Arterial flow conditions can be three-dimensional, time-dependent and "chaotic". This makes quantification of basic constructs such as stasis challenging. Local analysis of blood flow mechanics typically requires computational modeling of blood flow and careful analysis of the computed flow structure. A goal of this project was to develop methods to better quantify flow mechanics potentially relevant to thrombosis. Because thrombosis also generally depends on a series of biochemical reactions (coagulation) near the vessel wall, we also sought to incorporate consideration of this process. Namely, since simultaneous modeling of arterial hemodynamics and the coagulation cascade involves disparate spatial and temporal scales, the development of tractable reduced-order modeling of hemodynamics and coagulation was explored. Main accomplishments on these goals include the following: 

1. A mathematical model of near-wall transport was developed to reduce the computational cost of solving near-wall cardiovascular mass transport problems by orders of magnitude. In addition, while previous research has emphasized the role of wall shear stress as a frictional force on the inner vessel surface, this model underscored the potential role of wall shear stress on near-wall transport as well. 

2. Common computational methods used to study transport problems were found to be inefficient or inaccurate when applied to the near-wall transport problems that arise in modeling thrombotic potential in large vessels. Based on these findings, we developed and published a set of guidelines to help other researchers more efficiently solve near-wall cardiovascular mass transport problems numerically.

3. Coagulation models describing the reactions between the proteins and enzymes involved in clot formation generally require solving for the concentrations of dozens of reactive species. A framework was developed to systematically generate reduced-order models of this process that could maintain the basic dynamics. It was also found that a residence time measure defined through a single-species metric may be an effective surrogate for more comprehensive and computationally expensive multi-species models used to evaluate hemodynamics.  

4. A computational framework was used to study fluid mechanics surrounding modeled clot morphologies. The clot was modeled as a collection of discrete elements, which enables phenomena such as fracture and intraclot transport to be considered. This model was used to study flow features resulting from the interaction between a modeled clot and the surrounding fluid flow. 

5. A computational method to track near-wall particles in arterial flow simulations was developed and used to identify flow features underlying near-wall transport. Namely, the concepts of wall shear stress Lagrangian coherent structures (WSS LCS) and WSS fixed points, and their relations to near-wall transport, were described in two publications. 

Broader impacts

Computational modeling of blood flow has become increasingly used to study cardiovascular biomechanics. In particular, image-based modeling, which combines medical imaging and computational modeling, can enable "patient-specific" simulations that aim to improve diagnosis, treatment planning or understanding of cardiovascular function. Image-based modeling of blood flow has recently gained approval and clinical translation for the improved diagnosis of coronary artery disease, which exemplifies the potential of computational modeling to improve human healthcare.

Many image-based modeling research studies consider blood flow in large arteries (or veins), and there is often a direct or implicit objective to identify hemodynamic conditions that may promote thrombosis. For example, one may want to identify the potential for thrombosis in a given diseased artery or potential surgical design being considered. The research developed in this project offers methods to potentially improve the quantification of hemodynamic conditions relevant to thrombotic potential. 

On the human resources side, this project provided training for doctoral students, a postdoctoral scholar, and undergraduate student researchers. This included learning how to systematically approach research problems and gain familiarity with methods and progress in contemporary biomedical research. The doctoral students and postdoc were involved in several outreach activities, and gained technical skills (e.g., software development and mathematical methods) that will benefit their continued careers in engineering. Two of these trainees have developed, or are in the process of developing, their own research programs at new institutions shaped in part by research training provided through this project.
